C . 8 6 ( 3 9) C o n c l u s i o n 2 ) . This memorandum h a s b e e n d r a f t e d i n c l o se c o n s u l t a t i o n w i t h t h e o t h e r D e p a r t m e n t s c o n c e r n e d. ( G ) ( 3 9 ) 96) t h a t , even i f we a re unable t o t a k e any i m m e d i a t e a c t i o n t h e m a t t e r s h o u l d be k e pt under c l o s e r e v i e w . We n e e d n o t now d e c i d e t h a t no a c t i on should be t a k e n i n any c i r c u m s t a n c e s . All t h a t i s n e c e s s a r y is to d e c i d e w h e t h e r a c t i o n m i g h t u s e f u l l y be t a k e n i n p a r t i c u l ar d i r e c t i o n s no?/, a n d , i f s o , upon what l i n e s . From t h e p o i n t of v i e w of s h i p p i n g , I n e e d n o t e l a b o r a te the a d v a n t a g e s which would a c c r u e i f t h e a l l i e s were a b l e to secure e f f e c t i v e use of a l a r g e b l o c k of s h i p p i n g n o t o t h e r w i se a v a i l a b l e t o them. It may i n d e e d be a s k e d i n what o t h e r d i r e c t i on we could l o o k f o r any e q u i v a l e n t a u g m e n t a t i o n of, o u r t o n n a ge r e s o u r c e s . The o n l y s u b s t a n t i a l f i e l d f o r p u r c h a s e i s t he United S t a t e s and t h o u g h e n q u i r i e s t h e r e a r e b e i n g a c t i v e ly Pursued, t h e y may n o t be s u c c e s s f u l . As r e g a r d s t h e c h a r t e r i ng o f N e u t r a l s , e v e r y n e u t r a l c o u n t r y i s d e t e r m i n e d t o r e s e r v e f or i t s e l f a s u f f i c i e n t p r o p o r t i o n of i t s n a t i o n a l t o n n a g e t o m e e t, "^th an ample m a r g i n , i t s own r e q u i r e m e n t s . The n e g o t i a t i o ns which have b e e n s u c c e s s f u l l y c o n c l u d e d w i t h t h e N o r w e g i a ns - 1 so and the Swedes will only yield results as ships come off other voyages, and while progress has "been made in securing other neutral tonnage, it has not yet "been secured upon a scale adequate to our needs. The recent minings oh the east coast have checked the willingness of neutrals to charter to this country. If, therefore, unobjectionable means could "be found of getting the German shipping into employment either directly or indirectly, it might redound to our advantage. At least the general strain on shipping would be pro tanto relieved, and some check might possibly "be applied to the rising tendency of freights. On the other hand, there are formidable objections arising, first, by reason of the possible weakening of our position in international law with regard to rights of capture, and, secondly, from the strengthening of Germany^ financial position which would result from the sale of her ships. These various considerations are discussed in more detail "below. It is estimated (see Appendix I) that 1,1+60,000 tons gross of German shipping was sheltering in neutral ports at the "beginning of November. Of this some 590,000 tons gross is represented "by Passenger ships, 137,000 tons by Tankers and 735,000 tons by cargo ships. The passenger ships range from the "Bremen" of 51,000 tons down to small 1,200 ton ships, but the majority of them are useful cargo carriers with the advantage of greater speed than the average cargo ship possesses. The distribution of these vessels among the various neutral countries is an important factor in any estimate of the prospects, Qnd of the possible results, of their transfer to neutral flags. pirst come Spain and Spanish Colonies with 52 ships, and then Italy and Italian Colonies with i+9, the Dutch Colonies with 3 5, Portugal and Portuguese Colonies with 20. The number in the
United. S t a t e s i s o n l y h, "but i n o t h e r A m e r i c a n R e p u b l i c s t h e re a r e 52 s h i p s . Japan h a s 17 s h i p s. So l o n g as t h e s e v a r i o u s c o u n t r i e s m a i n t a i n t h e ir n e u t r a l i t y , t h e o n l y German s h i p s which a r e l i k e l y t o become a v a i l a b l e f o r a l l i e d u s e are ( a ) t h o s e which v e n t u r e out t o s e a and f a l l i n t o t h e hands of t h e A l l i e s ' n a v a l f o r c e s and a r e n o t sunk b e f o r e c a p t u r e and ( b ) any w h i c h c a n be o b t a i n e d t h r o u g h l e g a l p r o c e s s b a s ed e i t h e r on f a i l u r e by t h e German owners t o f u l f i l p r e - w ar o b l i g a t i o n s ( e . g . payment of i n t e r e s t on m o r t g a g e s h e l d by n e u t r a l or a l l i e d i n t e r e s t s ) or t o meet c u r r e n t o b l i g a t i o ns s u c h as d u e s and c h a r g e s. I t i s n o t l i k e l y t h a t t h e number of s h i p s w h i c h c o u l d be o b t a i n e d by t h e s e methods would h a v e any s u b s t a n t i a l e f f e c t on t h e t o n n a g e p o s i t i o n. So l o n g as t h e p r e s e n t p o s i t i o n o b t a i n s , t h e r e i s always t h e r i s k t h a t some of t h e s e s h i p s may e s c a p e t o s u p p l y enemy s u b m a r i n e s or c r u i s e r s or be t h e m s e l v e s c o n v e r t e d i n t o armed r a i d e r s . It i s a l s o p o s s i b l e t h a t , a f t e r t r a n s f e r t o c e r t a in n e u t r a l f l a g s , t h e s h i p s w o u l d , by r e a s o n of t h e g r e a t e r freedomof movement t h u s s e c u r e d , be a b l e t o a f f o r d n a v a l a s s i s t a n c e to Germany. If German crews were r e t a i n e d , t h e s e r i s k s would be i n c r e a s e d . We' c a n n o t i g n o r e t h e p o s s i b i l i t y t h a t some n e u t r a l s , e . g . S o v i e t R u s s i a or J a p a n , m i g h t f o r t h e i r own r e a s o n s . p u t i n t o o p e r a t i o n schemes f o r t h e t r a n s f e r of t he German s h i p s t o t h e i r own o r o t h e r n e u t r a l f l a g s . This p o s s i b i l i t y makes i t a l l t h e more i m p o r t a n t t o m a i n t a i n our p o s i t i o n i n i n t e r n a t i o n a l law. The p o s i t i o n u n d e r i n t e r n a t i o n a l law. T h e r e i s no doubt t h a t we a r e e n t i t l e d to r e g a r d w i th s u s p i c i o n t r a n s f e r s from an enemy t o a n e u t r a l f l a g e f f e c t ed d u r i n g h o s t i l i t i e s and t o b r i n g a s h i p so t r a n s f e r r e d b e f o re - 3 0 9 a p r i z e c o u r t f o r a d j u d i c a t i o n , and t h i s f a c t has so f ar e n a b l e d u s t o t a k e t h e g e n e r a l l i n e t h a t we w i l l n ot r e c o g n i s e t h e v a l i d i t y of s u c h t r a n s f e r s . It i s , h o w e v e r, d o u b t f u l w h e t h e r a B r i t i s h p r i z e c o u r t would i n s u c h c a s es hold t h e t r a n s f e r i n v a l i d . Under t h e u n r a t i f i e d D e c l a r a t i on of London t h e r e was a p r e s u m p t i o n t h a t a t r a n s f e r d u r i ng h o s t i l i t i e s was v o i d , w h i c h c o u l d o n l y b e r e b u t t e d by p r o v i ng t h a t t h e t r a n s f e r "was n o t made i n o r d e r t o evade t he c o n s e q u e n c e s t o which an enemy v e s s e l as such i s e x p o s e d " , and t h e p r e s u m p t i o n was a b s o l u t e i f t h e t r a n s f e r had b e e n made d u r i n g a v o y a g e or i n a b l o c k a d e d p o r t , or i f a r i g h t to r e p u r c h a s e o r r e c o v e r t h e v e s s e l was r e s e r v e d t o t h e v e n d o r. The Crown h a s , h o w e v e r , no power to i m p r o v e r u l e s upon a B r i t i sh p r i z e c o u r t u n l e s s t h o s e r u l e s c o n s t i t u t e a w a i v e r of b e l l i g e r e n t r i g h t s i n f a v o u r of t h e n e u t r a l , and t h i s makes i t i m p o s s i b l e t o i m p r o v e t h e D e c l a r a t i o n upon our P r i z e C o u r t, s i n c e i t s p r o v i s i o n s on t h i s p a r t i c u l a r p o i n t a r e i n f a c t more f a v o u r a b l e t o a b e l l i g e r e n t t h a n t h e r u l e l a i d down i n t he o l d P r i z e C o u r t c a s e s . I t would, o f c o u r s e , b e open t o t h e Crown t o e n d e a v o u r t o p e r s u a d e t h e C o u r t t h a t u n d e r modern c o n d i t i o ns t h e p r o v i s i o n s of t h e D e c l a r a t i o n on t h i s p o i n t a r e r e a s o n a b le and o u g h t t o b e a p p l i e d on t h e i r m e r i t s . The r u l e l a i d down i n t h e o l d B r i t i s h P r i z e c a s e s r e c o g n i s e d t r a n s f e r s i f made bona f i d e w i t h o u t any r e s e r v a t i o n of p r o f i t s o r c o n t r o l over t h e s h i p and w i t h o u t any power of r e v o c a t i o n or r e p u r c h a s e or c o n d i t i o n f o r h e r r e s t o r a t i o n a f t e r t h e c l o s e of t h e war. In a c a s e d u r i n g t h e l a s t war ( t h e "Edna") t h e P r i v y C o u n c il r e a f f i r m e d t h i s r u l e i n p l a c e of t h a t l a i d down i n t he D e c l a r a t i o n of London, and h e l d t h a t a t r a n s f e r was good " if t h e t r a n s f e r e e were a c t i n g i n good f a i t h w i t h o u t any p u r p o se of d e f e a t i n g t h e r i g h t s of t h e b e l l i g e r e n t ".
Since it can hardly he disputed that the transfers would not have taken place had not the German ships in question he en immobilised in port since the outbreak of s war, it i probable that in such cases the ships would be condemned if the Declaration of London rule were applied, and something might be made of this argument, even under the rules laid down by the British prize court. Moreover, it seems unlikely that Germany would sell the vessels without some arrangement for their return after the war. To some extent the decision in any particular case must depend upon the facts of the case, but the prospects of condemnation in a British prize court must be regarded as uncertain. The rule applied "by the French prize courts is much more favourable to the belligerent, and it has accordingly been proposed that, in the event of any such ships being seized, they should be taken into a French port and adjudicated upon by a French prize court. It is of course open to the Allied Governments to waive their rights under international law and to agree not to interfere with German vessels transferred to neutral flags. Prom the information in Appendix II regarding the attitude adopted in the war of 1914 - 1918, it will be seen that, after first maintaining their rights under international law, His Majesty's Government found it desirable in 1916, owing to the shortage of shipping, to modify their attitude and to agree in principle to the transfer of enemy ships to neutral flags subject to conditions which would guarantee that the enemy would not have control of the ships, directly or indirectly, and that only a moderate amount of money
Would r e a c h t h e enemy. The c o n d i t i o n s p r o p o s e d were so s t r i n g e nt however t h a t no t r a n s f e r s a p p e a r to h a v e t a k e n p l a c e s u b j e c t to them. The p o s i t i o n i s t h u s t h a t t h e A l l i e d Government a r e not "bound t o m a i n t a i n t h e i r p r e s e n t a t t i t u d e i f t h e y c o n s i d e r t h at they c a n on b a l a n c e g a i n a d v a n t a g e by d e p a r t i n g from i t . But i t must he r e c o g n i s e d t h a t a c q u i e s c e n c e i n any schemes of t r a n s er d e v i s e d i n t h e A l l i e s ' i n t e r e s t s m i g h t make i t d i f f i c u l t to b l o ck other schemes s p o n s o r e d by N e u t r a l G o v e r n m e n t s , even i f c a r r i ed out w i t h o u t any r e g a r d t o t h e A l l i e s ' i n t e r e s t s . U n f r i e n d ly n e u t r a l s m i g h t c a r r y t h r o u g h a f e i g n e d s e i z u r e or t r a n s f e r , and might hamper t h e e x e r c i s e of a r i g h t of c a p t u r e. F i n a n c i a l a d v a n t a g e to Germany. A m o s t m a t e r i a l c o n s i d e r a t i o n i s t h e e x t e n t to w h i ch Germany1 s f i n a n c i a l r e s o u r c e s would be e f f e c t i v e l y i n c r e a s e d if she were a b l e t o t r a n s f e r t h e s e v e s s e l s or any of them t o n e u t r al f l a g s . The t o t a l v a l u e of t h e s h i p s i s p r o b a b l y b e t w e e n £20 m i l l i o n and £30 m i l l i o n . If Germany c o u l d a c q u i r e b u t £10 m i l l i on from t h e s a l e of c e r t a i n of t h e s e v e s s e l s t h i s a l o n e would be a very s u b s t a n t i a l a d d i t i o n to h e r f i n a n c i a l r e s o u r c e s , which a re e s t i m a t e d t o h a v e b e e n a t most £k5 m i l l i o n of g o l d , and £15 m i l l i on of f o r e i g n e x c h a n g e a t t h e o u t b r e a k of ware In t erms of commodities £10 m i l l i o n would p u r c h a s e ubout 80/, of t h e i r o n o r e Germany is said to be d e m a n d i n g a n n u a l l y from Sweden, or 75'^ of h e r t o t al imports o f c r u d e p e t r o l e u m i n 1938, This o b j e c t i o n would be s u b s t a n t i a l l y met i f i t was p o s s i b l e to e n s u r e t h a t Germany would n o t i n a n y way b e n e f i t from t h e p r o c e e d s of any s a l e s u n t i l a f t er the war, b u t no e f f e c t i v e means of s e c u r i n g t h i s has so f a r b e en s u 5 g e s t e d . Indeed, i f s u c h r e s t r i c t i o n s c o u l d be made e f f e c t i v e, x t is i m p r o b a b l e t h a t Germany w o u l d s e l l h e r s h i p s.
0 A f u r t h e r i m p o r t a n t c o n s i d e r a t i o n i s t h a t t h e c h i e f d e f e n ce f the N e u t r a l s a d j a c e n t to Germany a g a i n s t p r e s s u r e from h e r h as t e e n Germany's d e b i t s i n t h e C l e a r i n g s , which h a v e j u s t i f i e d them in r e f u s i n g t o s e l l to Germany more t h a n n o r m a l q u a n t i t i e s of b a s ic commodities. A p a r t from t h e a d v a n t a g e of i n c r e a s i n g our t o n n a ge r e s o u r c e s , w h i c h m i g h t be a r e a s o n f o r t a k i n g t h e i n i t i a t i ve o u r s e l v e s , we h a v e t o c o n s i d e r our a t t i t u d e t o a number of p r o p o s a l s w h i c h h a v e b e e n made, some by G o v e r n m e n t s and some by commercial i n t e r e s t s , f o r t h e t r a n s f e r to v a r i o u s n e u t r a l f l a g s of German s h i p s now s h e l t e r i n g i n n e u t r a l p o r t s . P a r t i c u l a rs of t h e s e p r o p o s a l s a r e g i v e n i n A p p e n d i x I I I , Under i n s t r u c t i o ns from t h e F o r e i g n O f f i c e , B r i t i s h d i p l o m a t i c r e p r e s e n t a t i v e s have brought t h e l e g a l p o s i t i o n t o t h e r e c o l l e c t i o n of t h e g o v e r n m e n ts of the c o i v n t r i e o c o n c e r n e d ; and so l o n g as His M a j e s t y ' s. Government m a i n t a i n t h e same a t t i t u d e , t h e p r o p o s a l s a r e n ot l i k e l y t o make much h e a d w a y , at l e a s t so f a r as n o n - A m e r i c an c o u n t r i e s a r e c o n c e r n e d. I n t h e c a s e of A m e r i c a n c o u n t r i e s , a s p e c i a l p o s i t i o n e x i s ts in t h a t t h e r e s o l u t i o n s a d o p t e d by t h e r e c e n t c o n f e r e n c e of American S t a t e s at Panama i n c l u d e d a p a r a g r a p h d e c l a r i n g t h at those S t a t e s would " c o n s i d e r as l a w f u l t h e t r a n s f e r of t h e f l ag Q f a m e r c h a n t v e s s e l to t h a t of any A m e r i c a n R e p u b l i c p r o v i d e d such t r a n s f e r i s made i n good f a i t h , w i t h o u t a g r e e m e n t f o r r e s a l e to vendor and t h a t i t t a k e s p l a c e i n t h e w a t e r s of an American ^ P u b l i c . ships now i n A m e r i c a n p o r t s by a P a n - A m e r i c a n Combine, and JJT,, Sumner W e l l s , t h e Under S e c r e t a r y of S t a t e , h a s a l r e a dy d i s c u s s e d t h e q u e s t i o n g e n e r a l l y s e v e r a l t i m e s w i t h His M a j e s t y 's Ambassador a t W a s h i n g t o n . At p r e s e n t , he w i l l m e r e l y a s k , if -Dressed, what t h e U n i t e d S t a t e s Governments p r o p o s a l s a r e. Summary. On b a l a n c e t h e t o n n a g e r e s o u r c e s of t h e A l l i e s would be s u b s t a n t i a l l y i n c r e a s e d i f t h e employment of t h i s German t o n n a ge were p e r m i t t e d on a c c e p t a b l e c o n d i t i o n s and t h e t o n n a g e were handed o v e r i n r e a s o n a b l y good c o n d i t i o n. On t h e o t h e r h a n d , any g e n e r a l abandonment or r e l a x a t i on of our p o s i t i o n i n i n t e r n a t i o n a l law m i g h t be most i n e x p e d i e nt and t r a n s f e r s on any s u b s t a n t i a l s c a l e m i g h t , i n f a c t , put Germany i n p o s s e s s i o n of g r e a t l y i n c r e a s e d p u r c h a s i n g power in f o r e i g n c o u n t r i e s . It seems t o me t h a t t h e whole p o s i t i o n s h o u ld be f u r t h e r examined i n d e t a i l in r e l a t i o n t o t h e c i r c u m s t a n c e s of p a r t i c u l a r n e u t r a l c o u n t r i e s and t h a t f o r t h e moment i t would be premature t o a t t e m p t t o f o r m u l a t e a g e n e r a l p o l i c y , If, for example, one of t h e more f r i e n d l y n e i v t r a l s were a b l e t o d i s t r a in for any r e a s o n upon a German s h i p so t h a t t h e s h i p would become the l a w f u l p r o p e r t y of a n e u t r a l no d i f f i c u l t y or e m b a r r a s s m e nt would a r i s e . Any s u c h p r o c e s s would no doubt be l i m i t e d and slow b u t i t may b e a d v i s a b l e t o s t a r t s l o w l y. I t w i l l a l s o be n e c e s s a r y to c o - o r d i n a t e our p o l i c y w i th that of P r a n c e , w h i c h can p e r h a p s b e s t be done t h r o u g h t h e new Permanent E x e c u t i v e Committee which i s t o d e a l w i t h economic warfare. A p p e n d i x II. Transfers of enemy ships to neutral flags In war of 1914-18. Hireamstances in which His Majesty1 s Government recognised transfers of enemy ships to noutral flags during the last war. Policy adopted In 1914-1015 uric), deviations therefrom. On the outbreak of hostilities in 1914, the policy adopted by the Allies was one of strict insietance oh their belligerent rights under Articles 56 of the Declaration of London, but their position was soon, threatened by action on the part of the United States Government which culminated Ln the passing of a bill for the admission to United States registry of foreignbuilt ships which had previously been Illegal. When this became lav/ (3,8th August, 1914) many United States-owned vessels transferred from the German to the United States flag. As o matter of policy the Allies refrained from interfering with these transfers and agreed not to dispute them provided that ( 1) the vessels carried a United. States Government cert LX'ica fce that the beneficial ownership in them was solely American before the outbreak of war; (2) there was no grouno for suspicion that the vessels were trading with enemy countries; (£5) no money wan to pans Ln to enemy hands Ln connection '//J th the transfer, and (4) no enemy nationals were employed on board. Subject to these; conditions, His Majesty^ Government recognised the transfer to United. States registry of 26 vessels belonging to German subsidiaries owned by the standard. Oil Company. A similar agreement was made with the Chilean Government, who had adopted a friendly attitude on the outbreak of war but " 0 transfer was actually made the proposals being abandoned
by t h e C h i l e a n Government. The c o n d i t i o n s g o v e r n i n g t h is . t r a n s f e r to t h e C h i l e a n f l a g were t o have b e e n ( l ) t h a t t h e t r a n s f e r was b o n a f i d e and c o m p l e t e , w i t h o u t a r i g h t t o r e - p u r c h a s e a t t h e end of t h e war b e i n g r e s e r v e d t o t he v e n d o r , ( 2 ) t h a t t h e enemy o f f i c e r s and men w e r e r e m o v e d , and ( 3 ) t h a t t h e v e s s e l s were n o t u s e d t o t r a d e d i r e c t l y or i n d i r e c t l y w i t h t h e enemy d u r i n g t h e war. Change of p o l i c y i n 1 9 1 6. By J a n u a r y , 1 9 1 6 , t h e t o n n a g e s h o r t a g e h a d become so g r a ve t h a t His M a j e s t y ' s Government were c o m p e l l e d t o modify t h e ir p o l i c y . A f t e r c o n s u l t a t i o n s w i t h t h e F r e n c h i t was d e c i d e d to a g r e e t o t h e t r a n s f e r of enemy s h i p s t o n e u t r a l f l a g s s u b j e c t to c o n d i t i o n s which would g u a r a n t e e t h a t the enemy w o u l d n o t have c o n t r o l of the s h i p s e i t h e r d i r e c t l y or i n d i r e c t l y , and t h a t o n ly a m o d e r a t e amount of money would be p a i d t o enemy c o u n t r i e s. The d e t a i l e d t r a n s a c t i o n s were i n t h e h a n d s of t h e Board of Trade who imposed t h e f o l l o w i n g c o n d i t i o n s : ( l ) Only v e s s e l s v/hich a c c e p t e d a n d were bound by His M a j e s t y ' s G o v e r n m e n t ' s c o n d i t i o n s were exempt f r om c a p t u r e. ( 2 ) The v e s s e l s were t o be e m p l o y e d a t a p p r o v e d r a t e s. ( 3 ) They were t o be d i s c h a r g e d to a p p r o v e d B r i t i s h f i r m s and employed i n the s e r v i c e of t h e A l l i e s. ( 4 ) No i n t e r e s t s i n t h e s h i p s t o be a l i e n a t e d w i t h o u t the c o n s e n t of His M a j e s t y ' s Government f o r 10 y e a r s a f t e r the c o n c l u s i o n of war. ( 5 ) The s a l e to be c o m p l e t e a n d b o n a f i d e. ( 6 ) The v e s s e l s to t r a d e e x c l u s i v e l y b e t w e e n p o r t s of the B r i t i s h Empire a n d / o r t h o s e of A l l i e d c o u n t r i e s. No t r a n s f e r s a p p e a r t o have t a k e n p l a c e on t h e s e c o n d i t i o n s, P a r t l y owing t o t h e s t r i n g e n t terms demanded by H i s M a j e s t y 's
l e o Government and partly on account of the refusal of enemy governments to allow the sale of their vessels. The conditions were thereupon modified to allow enemy ships to he placed in purely inter-neutral trade provided that an equivalent amount of tonnage was released for trade with Allied countries at reasonable rates, and proper guarantees were obtained regarding the manner in which the ships were controlled. In some cases the additional condition was made that the purchase money should not pass to the owners until after the conclusion of peace. It is not known whether any transfers actually took place under these conditions.
